comment.author: 52437490@N08
comment._content: did this plane just crash recently or is this something from a crash years ago

comment.author: 26738691@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sandy739123] Decades ago! This feed is all from an archive of photos from aviation history. I think this one is the one crashed in the 40's and recovered in the 90's, as described here: "A Grumman F3F-2 was ditched off the coast of San Diego on 29 August 1940 while attempting a landing on Saratoga. The fighter was rediscovered by a navy submarine in June 1988, and recovered on 5 April 1991. It was restored at the San Diego Aerospace Museum."

comment.author: 9039089@N07
comment._content: An excellent photograph that I see, as all I could see in your gallery, all with the signature of a good knowledge of photography. My sincere congratulations for that. Kind regards. vagabu.blogspot.com.es/

comment.author: 28288340@N03
comment._content: It's amazing that so much of the aircraft is in such good shape after being in salt water for over 50 years.  The lack of barnacles and other ocean creatures seems odd.  I wonder if this aircraft was actually recovered from a cold fresh water lake (i.e. Lake Michagan)?  Lots of Navy and Marine aviators were trained on the Navy's Lake Michigan paddlewheel aircraft carrier.

comment.author: 49487266@N07
comment._content: Amazingly, this F3F was at the bottom of the Pacific for several decades!
comment.authorname: San Diego Air & Space Museum Archives

comment.author: 28288340@N03
comment._content: Wow!  That is amazing.  I would have thought this classic would have been unrecognizable after 50+ years in the Pacific Ocean.

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
The craft is mostly intact, the wings are not in as good as shape as I've seen other raise warbirds… yet, what makes it so remarkable is the clear markings, the paint that didn't fade or wash away after all those years under the water… Same with the yellow coverings on the wings… That would be one of the first things to deteriorate. Unless this was a later restoration and was a victim of a more recent crash… I could be wrong but, it's hard to believe that it sat in salt water for over 60 years… This is a pre-war craft. 

Amazing.
